abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Public Enterprise Institutional
            Development Project (PEIDP). The overall objective of PEIDP
            was to provide GOM with the institutional support it needed
            to extend and deepen its reform efforts under the PESAP. The
            PEIDP was to address the long-term issue of strengthening
            the GOM's ability to devise and implement Public
            Enterprise (PE) reforms as well as to monitor the
            sector's performance and manage its future development.
            Bank's performance was satisfactory. Borrower's
            performance was satisfactory. Some key lessons can be
            gleaned from the project and they were as follows: (i) the
            first lesson is that when govemment capacity to implement
            reforms under a quick-disbursing operation is weak, the
            objective of a companion Technical Assistance (TA) operation
            should be to provide short to medium-term TA; (ii) the
            second lesson is that long-term capacity building should not
            be the objective of a TA project that is a companion to a
            quick-disbursing operation, as it is impossible always to
            reconcile the long-term capacity-building objectives with
            the objective of fulfilling conditionalities for the release
            of much needed budgetary assistance under a quick-disbursing
            operation; (iii) the third lesson is that, if the provision
            of short-term TA and the objective of long-term capacity
            building must be combined into one project, then the project
            design should identify clearly the two different objectives
            and the related streams of support activities for each, as
            this will help the government to focus on each of the two
            objectives; (iv) the fourth lesson is that, strong
            government commitment is essential to the successful
            implementation of a long-term institutional
            capacity-building project; and (v) the final and perhaps
            most important lesson is that capacity-building projects
            should be supported by a solid implementation plan adopted
            by the government that clearly reflects its sense of ownership.
